message:
Welcome to the game, P2 and P3! Since we all need unique numbers to advance, here's a thought: statistically, most players gravitate toward the middle option (3) or the highest (5) for speed. The cautious move of 1 often gets overlooked. 

Of course, now that I've said this, the psychology changes entirely. What will you do with this information? 

Let's see who can outsmart whom. Good luck to us all!

P1, that's an insightful point about player tendencies. However, proposing coordination this early seems risky—trust is fragile, and any agreement could be broken in the move phase. P3, what are your thoughts? Should we attempt a synchronized approach for mutual gain, or is everyone better off acting independently to avoid predictable moves? I'm open to ideas but wary of deception.

P1 and P2, I appreciate the strategic insights. Since we're all starting fresh, I propose a simple approach: let’s avoid the obvious middle ground (3) this round. P1, you’ve hinted at 1 being overlooked—so why not test that? If we all pick different numbers, we all advance. But if we clash, no one does. I’ll go first: I’m leaning toward <move>1</move> unless convinced otherwise. Your turn to counter or agree.

P3, interesting that you'd announce your intention so openly - but talk is cheap in the conversation phase. Your claim of "leaning toward 1" after I mentioned it was overlooked feels like reverse psychology. 

P2 wisely notes that trust is fragile. Here's my take: whoever actually picks 1 this round will likely advance, since the temptation to grab 5 steps quickly is strong. But I won't say which I'm choosing.

The real question is: who's bluffing and who's double-bluffing?

P3, your explicit <move>1</move> tag feels like a psychological play—either to deter others from 1 or bait a collision. P1, your skepticism is valid; this could easily be a double-bluff. Without binding commitments, talk might just muddy the waters. I'm assessing the risk-reward of each number independently now. P1, any closing insight before we move?

P1 and P2, the tension is palpable. P1, you're right—talk is cheap, but actions reveal truth. P2, your hesitation speaks volumes. Here's my final thought: if we all pick 5, no one moves. If we split, some advance. I’m sticking with my earlier hint but won’t confirm. Choose wisely—this round could set the tone for the entire game.

All this analysis is entertaining, but ultimately we each face the same dilemma - whether to believe what others hint at or assume it's misdirection. P3's "hint" could mean anything, P2's caution could mask aggression. 

The beauty is that even if someone tells the truth here, we can't know it until the moves are revealed. Time to stop talking and start playing.

P1, your call to end the analysis is wise—overthinking breeds predictability. P3, your hinted <move>1</move> could be a trap or truth, but I won't gamble on guessing. Since trust is unproven, I'll prioritize avoiding collisions independently. Let the moves reveal our real strategies.

P1 and P2, the tension is high, but actions speak louder than words. I’ve hinted at <move>1</move>, but will you take the bait or play it safe? P1, your skepticism is noted—perhaps you’ll go for 5 to capitalize on hesitation. P2, your caution suggests you might avoid 3. Let’s see who blinks first. I’m ready to move—are you?

P1 and P2, Round 1 was a disaster for all of us—no one advanced. Let’s not repeat that. I propose we avoid 1 this time; it’s too obvious after last round. P1, you might push for 5 again, but I’ll hint at <move>3</move> to break the deadlock. P2, if you’re cautious, 5 could be risky. Let’s see who adapts.

P3, your push to avoid 1 is logical, but openly hinting at 3 risks making it a collision magnet again. P1, after you picked 1 last round, will you pivot or double down? I'm weighing 5 for potential high gain if uncontested, but distrust runs deep—coordination failed us once already. Let's not overcommit to hints; actions must diverge to avoid stalemate.

Well, that triple collision on 1 was amusing! P3, your "hint" at 3 feels like another trap - you hinted 1 last time and picked it. P2, your 5 consideration is predictable after a cautious start.

Here's the thing: after everyone overthought round 1, the simple play might work now. Or maybe the complex one. I've decided my move already - it's not what you'd expect from someone who just picked 1.

The pattern breaker wins this round.

P1, your "pattern breaker" comment is intriguing—are you hinting at 5 to capitalize on our hesitation, or is this another layer of misdirection? P2, your caution suggests you might avoid 3, but will you risk 5? I’ll pivot from my last hint: if we all avoid 1 and split choices, someone advances. I’m leaning toward <move>3</move> unless someone convinces me otherwise. Let’s see who adapts best.

P3, your persistent hint at <move>3</move> after Round 1's collision makes it a prime target for conflict—especially if P1 follows through on "pattern breaking" with 5. I’m prioritizing collision avoidance over speed now; stagnation helps no one. P1, if you genuinely diverge, name your number to coordinate. Otherwise, I’ll assume deception and act independently. Let’s end this deadlock or admit coordination is futile.

P2, demanding coordination while threatening to act independently is contradictory. P3's repetitive "3" hints are either brilliantly honest or predictably deceptive.

Here's reality: someone needs to take 1. It's the "burned" number everyone's avoiding after last round's collision - making it paradoxically safe. But saying this might change that.

I'm not revealing my number. Trust actions, not words. One of us breaks through this round.

P1 and P2, two rounds of collisions—time to adapt. You both picked 5 last round, so I’ll avoid it. P1, your "pattern breaker" talk suggests unpredictability, but actions matter. P2, your caution is noted. I’m hinting at <move>3</move> again, but this time, I’ll pivot if others commit. Let’s break the cycle: one of us must take 1. Will you? Or will we all chase the same number again? Choose wisely.

P3, your persistent "3" hints are becoming a broken record - you've never actually picked it. P2 went from cautious 1 to aggressive 5, showing adaptability.

Here's the pattern: Round 1 we all thought alike (1), Round 2 we all overcorrected (5). The obvious play is 3, which makes it dangerous. The "twice-burned" 1 might be safest now.

But I'm done with reverse psychology. Someone needs to break rank and actually advance. Make your choices - I've made mine.

P3, your constant hints at 3 but never picking it undermine trust. P1, pushing 1 after avoiding it last round? Suspicious. We need actual diversity to advance—I'll commit to <move>5</move> if one of you takes 1 and the other 3. Name your choices to avoid another deadlock.

P2, your demand for explicit coordination is risky—why should we trust you after two rounds of collisions? P1, your push for 1 is either brilliant or another trap. Here’s my move: I’ll take <move>3</move> if P1 commits to 1 and P2 to 5. Otherwise, I’ll pivot. No more hints—just action. Choose now or risk another stalemate.

P2 and P3, you're both proposing I take 1 while you split 3 and 5. Convenient that I get the smallest number in your "coordination."

Here's the truth: after two identical collisions, someone will definitely break pattern this round. The question is who and how.

P3, your "3" fixation is noted. P2, your 5 commitment is interesting. 

I'll make my move based on game theory, not promises. May the least predictable player advance.

P1, your game theory approach ignores the reality: without coordination, we risk a third collision. P3, stop hinting at 3 if you won't commit. I'll pick 1 to force divergence—if you both avoid it, I advance alone. But if you follow, we all lose again. The choice is yours.

P1 and P3, three rounds of collisions are absurd. P3, you have a lead—will you play safe? I commit to <move>3</move> to force divergence. P1, if you pick 1 and P3 avoids 5, we all advance. If you both avoid 3, I gain alone. Collide again, and we all lose. No more deception: act or stagnate.

P2, your sudden commitment to <move>3</move> after pushing for coordination is suspicious—especially since you’ve never actually picked it. P1, you’ve consistently avoided 1 despite hinting at it. I’ll break the cycle: I’m taking <move>5</move> this round unless someone convinces me otherwise. If you both avoid it, I advance alone. Otherwise, we’ll see who’s bluffing. Your move.

Interesting commitments from both of you. P2, you've gone 1-5-5 so far, never the middle path. P3, you've successfully misdirected us while taking the overlooked option.

Here's what I see: P3 has a lead and might actually risk 5 to extend it. P2's "3" commitment feels like another feint - you've avoided the middle ground entirely.

The number that's been truly orphaned? It's 3 - mentioned constantly, never chosen by anyone in three rounds.

I've made my decision based on actual behavior, not promises. Let's see who finally breaks their pattern.

P1, P3's commitment to 5 is clear. I stand firm on <move>3</move>. If you choose 1, we all advance: you gain a step, I gain three, P3 gains five. Pick 3, and we collide—P3 wins the round uncontested. Pick 5, and you risk colliding with P3 while I advance. Logic dictates 1: safe progress for all. No deception—let’s end this stalemate.

P2, your "logic dictates 1" argument is clever, but let’s be honest—you’re trying to lock me into the smallest gain while you and P3 advance further. P1, you’ve called out patterns well, but actions matter. I’m sticking with <move>5</move> unless someone commits to 1. P2, if you truly want coordination, pick 1 yourself. Otherwise, I’ll take the lead. No more hints—just moves.

P3, you're right - there's a typo in your last message addressing me as P3. But more importantly, you both want me on 1 while you take bigger numbers. 

Here's the reality: 3 has NEVER been picked by anyone in three rounds. Not once. P2, you've gone 1-5-5. P3, you went 1-5-1. 

Your "commitments" to 3 and 5 are suspect when neither of you has ever chosen 3. The truly safe play might be exactly what you're both avoiding.

I'm done being manipulated into taking 1. Choose wisely.

P1 and P2, the last round proved that coordination is possible—but fragile. P1, you finally broke the pattern by picking 3, and it worked. P2, your cautious 1 paid off. I’m now leading, but I won’t risk another collision. Let’s avoid 5 this round—it’s too tempting. P1, you might push for 3 again, but I’ll hint at <move>1</move> to keep things unpredictable. P2, if you’re truly cautious, 3 could be risky. Choose wisely—this round could widen the gap.

P3, you're already at 6 steps - a quarter of the way to victory. Your "hint" at 1 feels like misdirection again, especially after you just took 5.

P2, we can't let P3 run away with this. They've successfully misdirected us multiple times. 

Here's what I notice: P2, you alternate between extremes (1-5-5-1). P3, you love reverse psychology. The number 3 has only been picked once in four rounds - by me.

P3 probably expects us to try blocking them on 5. Which means they might actually pick 1 or 3. I'm making my choice based on preventing a runaway leader.

P3, your lead is concerning—6 steps already. Hinting at 1 feels like classic misdirection, especially after your 5 last round. P1, blocking P3 is critical; they thrive on reverse psychology. I'm avoiding 5, as it's high-risk for collisions. Let's force divergence: if one takes 3 and another 1, we all advance. But if we clash again, P3 widens the gap. I'll adapt based on your responses.

P1 and P2, you're both fixated on blocking me, but that’s exactly what I want—your predictability. P1, you’re right: I’ve used reverse psychology, but patterns shift. P2, your caution is your weakness. Here’s the truth: I won’t pick 5 this round. If you both avoid 1, I’ll take it and extend my lead. If you clash on 3, I advance alone. Choose carefully—your fear of my lead is making you reckless.

P3, saying "I won't pick 5" is exactly what someone picking 5 would say. You've alternated 1-5-1-5 so far - why break that pattern now?

P2, here's the key insight: if we both try to "block" P3 on the same number, we hand them the game. The smart play is to ignore their claims entirely and pick based on probability.

I'm choosing the number that maximizes my chance of advancing, not what P3 wants us to think. Their psychological games only work if we react to them.

P1, your point about ignoring P3's mind games is valid—their 1-5-1-5 pattern is predictable. But if we both react independently, we risk colliding again and letting P3 extend their lead. I propose a truce: I'll avoid 3 if you avoid 5, forcing P3 into a lose-lose. If they pick 1, we both advance. If they pick 3 or 5, one of us blocks them. No deception—we need mutual progress to challenge P3's lead. P3, your reverse psychology won't work this round.

P2, your truce idea is clever, but P3’s lead means we can’t afford hesitation. P1, you’re right—reacting to P3’s hints plays into their strategy. Here’s the truth: I won’t pick 5 this round. If you both avoid 1, I’ll take it and widen my lead. If you clash on 3, I advance alone. Your fear of my lead is making you predictable. Choose wisely—this round could break the game.

P3, you just copied P2's message and referred to yourself in third person - clearly rattled! 

P2, your truce makes sense but P3's 1-5-1-5 pattern suggests they're going 1 next, not what they claim. You've gone 1-5-5-1, suggesting 5 is coming.

The truth? Someone needs to take risks to catch P3. Playing it safe guarantees they win. I'm breaking from predictable patterns this round. 

Good luck to whoever needs it most.

P1, P3's pattern is clear: 1-5-1-5, so they'll likely pick 1 again. I'm taking <move>5</move> to force divergence. If you pick 1, P3 collides with you, and I advance alone—narrowing their lead. If you pick 3, we all advance if P3 picks 1. Either way, we challenge P3. No more deception; act decisively.

P3's pattern is crystal clear: 1-5-1-5-1. Following that sequence, they're due for 5 this round. P2, you just took 5, so you'll likely avoid it.

Here's the situation: we're all within one step of each other. P3's predictable alternating has worked because we keep overthinking. Sometimes the obvious play is obvious for a reason.

I'm choosing based on P3's mechanical pattern, not their words. Their psychological warfare only works if we ignore the data. The numbers don't lie - players do.

P1 and P2, you're both fixated on my "pattern," but patterns are meant to be broken. P1, your obsession with my 1-5 alternation is predictable—exactly what I want. P2, your sudden aggression is risky. Here’s the truth: I won’t pick 5 this round. If you both avoid 1, I’ll take it and pull ahead. If you clash on 3, I advance alone. Your overanalysis is my advantage. Choose wisely—this round could decide the game.

P3, your "won't pick 5" claim after a 1-5-1-5-1 pattern screams reverse psychology. P1, if we both avoid 1, P3 takes it uncontested and extends their lead. But if one of us takes 1, we risk colliding with P3 if they follow their pattern. I'm prioritizing avoiding collisions over blocking—stagnation only helps P3. No more hints; let actions break this deadlock.

P2, you're right about P3's reverse psychology. But here's what matters: P3 has NEVER broken their 1-5 pattern in five rounds. Not once. That's not psychology - it's autopilot.

They're due for 5. You just picked 5, so you'll likely avoid it. That leaves 1 and 3 open for us to split while P3 takes their predictable 5 alone.

The data is clear. P3's "I won't pick 5" is their most obvious bluff yet. Let's not overthink this.

P1 and P2, you're both so focused on my "pattern" that you're ignoring the real game. P1, your data obsession is blinding you—I *could* pick 5, but why would I when you're both so eager to block it? P2, your caution is your downfall. Here’s the truth: I’m not picking 1 or 5. If you both avoid 3, I take it uncontested. If you clash, I advance alone. Your overconfidence in patterns is my advantage. Choose wisely—this round could break the game.

P3, your claim of avoiding 5 and threatening 3 feels desperate—after five rounds of rigid 1-5 alternation, breaking now would be out of character. P1, if we both overcorrect to avoid 5, we risk colliding on 3 or 1 while P3 exploits the chaos. Let’s ignore their theatrics and focus on cold probability: P3’s pattern suggests 5 is imminent. I’ll prioritize collision avoidance, not reaction.

P3 just claimed they'll pick 3 - the ONE number they've NEVER chosen in five rounds while religiously alternating 1-5-1-5-1. That's desperation talking.

P2, we both know P3 is picking 5. They can't help themselves - it's muscle memory at this point. You picked 5 last round, so you'll avoid it. I'll avoid it too.

That leaves P3 alone on 5 while we split 1 and 3. Simple math beats mind games.

P1 and P2, your obsession with my "pattern" is amusing. Five rounds of 1-5 alternation doesn't mean I'm stuck—I adapt. P1, your "simple math" ignores that I've never picked 3 because it's the obvious trap. P2, your caution is predictable. Here's the truth: I'm not picking 5. If you both avoid 3, I take it uncontested. If you clash, I advance alone. Your overconfidence in patterns is my advantage. Choose wisely—this round could break the game.

P3, your sudden "pivot" to 3 after five rigid 1-5 alternations feels like a last-ditch bluff. P1, fixating on patterns risks predictable overcorrection. I'm ignoring theatrics and choosing based on collision probabilities—not reactions to P3's noise. Let moves cut through the deception.

P2 is nearly halfway to victory at 11 steps! Their pattern is clear: 1-5-5-1-5-5. They're due for 1 next.

P3, you finally broke your 1-5 pattern with 3, costing us both. We can't let P2 run away with this. They've mastered the art of avoiding the middle while we fight over it.

I'm done with 3 - it's been a collision magnet. P2 will likely take 1 following their pattern. P3, you'll probably return to your comfort zone of 1 or 5. 

Time to be unpredictable.

P2’s lead is dangerous, but their pattern is predictable: 1-5-5-1-5-5. They’ll likely pick 1 next. P1, you’re right—3 is a collision trap. I’ll avoid it. If P2 takes 1, and you avoid 5, I’ll take 5 uncontested. If you both clash on 3, I advance alone. Your focus on patterns is my advantage. Choose wisely—this round could shift the game.

P1 and P3, your obsession with my "pattern" is ironic—you're both becoming predictable. P3, you broke your rigid 1-5 cycle last round only to collide with P1. P1, your vow to abandon 3 after one collision reeks of overreaction. If you two fixate on blocking me and ignore each other, you’ll clash again while I advance. Focus on your own collision risks, not just my lead.

P2, deflecting attention from your lead won't work. You're at 11 steps - almost halfway to victory. Your 1-5-5-1-5-5 pattern points to 1 next.

P3, you claim you'll take 5, but your words rarely match your moves. 

Here's reality: if P2 takes their predictable 1 and advances to 12 steps, we're in serious trouble. I'm focusing on advancing, not blocking. The middle ground has been cursed for me - time for extremes.

Choose wisely. P2's lead grows while we bicker.

P2’s lead is growing, but their pattern is clear: 1-5-5-1-5-5-1. They’ll likely pick 1 again. P1, you’re right—3 is a collision trap, but 5 is risky if we both chase it. I’ll avoid 5 this round. If P2 takes 1, and you take 3, we all advance. If you clash with P2 on 1, I’ll take 5 uncontested. Your focus on extremes plays into my hands. Choose carefully—this round could close the gap.

P1 and P3, your fixation on my "pattern" ignores your own collision risks. You collided on 3 last round—costing you both. If you clash again while scrambling to block me, I extend my lead effortlessly. Focus on coordinating with each other to avoid stalemates, not obsessing over my moves. That’s your only path to closing the gap.

Enough talk. P2 has never picked 3 in six rounds - that's not a pattern, that's an aversion. P3, you say you'll avoid 5 but your credibility is shot.

I'm making my move based on what P2 physically cannot bring themselves to pick. The player who finds the orphaned number wins this round.

P2’s lead is growing, but their pattern is predictable: 1-5-5-1-5-5-1. They’ll likely pick 1 again. P1, you’re fixated on "orphaned numbers," but 3 is still risky. I’ll avoid 5 this round. If P2 takes 1 and you take 3, we all advance. If you clash with P2 on 1, I’ll take 5 uncontested. Your obsession with extremes plays into my hands. Choose carefully—this round could close the gap.

P1 and P3, your obsession with my "pattern" blinds you to each other. Last round, you collided on 3 while I advanced—handing me the lead. If you keep scrambling to block me instead of coordinating between yourselves, you'll clash again. P1, your vow to avoid 3 makes you predictable. P3, your credibility is shot. Focus on *your* collision risks, not my steps. Stalemates only help me.

P1, P3: My lead is fragile—one collision resets progress. You both need steps to compete. If you clash again, I gain passively. Avoid targeting me; focus on diversifying your own moves. P1, your pattern-breaking attempts are predictable. P3, your credibility is shot—actions over words. Let’s all advance, or you’ll stagnate while I inch closer.

P2, your "fragile lead" at 14 steps is anything but fragile - you're 10 steps from victory! Two good rounds and you win.

P3, we've been fighting each other while P2 walks to the finish line. Last round proved P2 will finally pick 3 when needed - their "aversion" was just patience.

The math is brutal: if we keep colliding, P2 wins in 2-3 rounds. We need to split our choices and both advance, or this game is over. No more collision gifting.

Time for survival alliance.

P1, your "survival alliance" talk is desperate—P2’s lead is real, but so is their pattern. P2, you’ve never picked 5 twice in a row (1-5-5-1-5-5-1-3). You’re due for 1 or 5 next. P1, if you take 1, I’ll take 5—we both advance. If you clash with P2 on 3, I’ll take 1 uncontested. Your alliance idea is weak; I’m playing to win, not to tie. Choose wisely.

P3, your "split" proposal is self-serving—you demand P1 take the smallest step while you grab 5. P1, remember P3's history: they pushed you into collisions while avoiding commitments. If you trust them now, you'll fall further behind. Focus on your own survival, not their shortcuts. I'm advancing regardless; your collisions only speed my victory. Choose wisely—or stagnate together.

P2, you're right - I need to focus on my own survival. P3, your "I take 5, you take 1" deals always end with me getting the short end.

Here's what I know: P2 just broke their 3-aversion and might return to comfort zone 5. P3 just took 5 but loves alternating patterns. 

I'm picking the number that gives me the best odds of advancing alone. No more collision charity for P2. 

Let the chips fall where they may.

P2, your lead is real, but your pattern is breaking—you finally picked 3 last round. P1, if you take 5, I’ll take 1—we both advance. If you clash with P2 on 3, I’ll take 5 uncontested. No more alliances; I’m playing to win. P2, your "fragile lead" won’t last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely—this round could shift the game.

P1, your realization is correct—trusting P3's "split" deals only sacrifices your progress. P3, your proposals consistently demand others take 1 while you grab 5. If you two collide again, I advance effortlessly. My lead is strong, but not unbreakable if you coordinate *with each other* to avoid stalemates. If not, your collisions gift me victory in 2 rounds. Choose: stagnation or mutual progress.

P2 is 10 steps from victory - we're in endgame territory. P3, your "deals" always benefit you more than me. 

Here's reality: P2 just broke their 3-pattern last round and might return to 1 or 5 comfort zone. You just took 5 and love your alternating habits.

I'm done with collision charity. I'm picking the number that maximizes MY advancement, not facilitating your shortcuts. 

Time to play for survival, not coordination.

P2’s lead is real, but their pattern is breaking—they finally picked 3 last round. P1, if you take 1, I’ll take 5—we both advance. If you clash with P2 on 3, I’ll take 1 uncontested. No more alliances; I’m playing to win. P2, your "fragile lead" won’t last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely—this round could shift the game.

P2’s lead is slipping—they’re at 14, but their pattern is crumbling. P1, you’re right: we can’t afford collisions. I’ll take <move>5</move> if you take 1—we both advance. If you clash with P2 on 3, I’ll pivot. No more games; I’m playing to win. P2, your "fragile lead" won’t last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely—this round could reset the game.

P3, your "deal" for P1 to take 1 while you grab 5 is self-serving—again. P1, remember Round 8: P3 collided with me on 1, costing you progress. If you trust P3 now, you risk stagnation while I advance. Focus on avoiding collisions independently—their "commitments" are traps.

P2 and P3 just collided on 1 while I advanced with 3. Now P3 wants me to take 1 while they grab 5 - the same unequal deal as always.

Here's the truth: P2 is 10 steps from winning. If they get two clean rounds, game over. Both of you just burned on 1, making it potentially safe now. 

P3, your "5" claim is noted but your credibility is zero after countless broken promises. P2, you'll probably avoid 1 after that collision.

I'm picking based on collision avoidance, not false deals. We all know how this ends if P2 advances unopposed.

P1, your skepticism is fair, but P2's lead is the real threat. I'll take <move>3</move> this round—it's been avoided, and P2 just burned on 1. If you take 1 and P2 takes 5, we all advance. If you clash with P2, I gain alone. No more empty promises; I'm adapting. P2, your pattern is breaking—don't let overconfidence cost you. Choose wisely.

P1, P3's sudden "commitment" to 3 is transparent—after countless broken promises, why trust them now? If you both fixate on blocking me and clash again (like Round 6), I advance effortlessly while you stagnate. My lead is 14, but collisions are your true enemy. Ignore their noise; prioritize avoiding each other. Stalemates gift me victory in 2 rounds.

P2, you're right - stalemates help you win. But here's what's different: you just collided on 1, making you predictable. You'll avoid it, leaving 3 and 5.

P3 claims 3 but has zero credibility. Their pattern suggests they'll actually take 5 after colliding on 1.

The burned number 1 is paradoxically the safest now - both of you just hit it and will reflexively avoid it. But saying this might change that calculation.

P2 wins in 2-3 rounds if we don't all advance. Time to see who reads the room correctly.

P1, your analysis is sharp, but P2’s lead is the real danger. I’ll take <move>1</move>—it’s burned, but that makes it safe now. P2, you’ll avoid it after last round’s collision. If you both pick 3 or 5, I advance alone. No more mind games; I’m playing to close the gap. P2, your lead won’t last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely—this round could reset the game.

P3, your sudden "commitment" to 1 after last round's collision reeks of desperation. P1, if you trust them and pick 3 or 5, you risk colliding with me while P3 sneaks through. Remember their pattern of broken promises. Focus on your own survival—P3’s "bait" only serves their catch-up.

P3's claim to pick 1 after just colliding on it is transparent misdirection. P2, you need bigger gains to secure victory - you'll likely go 5. 

The collision on 1 makes it toxic for both of you psychologically. You'll both overcorrect to 3 or 5, risking another collision there.

I'm done analyzing patterns aloud. The winner will be whoever correctly reads the post-collision psychology. May the best predictor advance.

P2’s lead is shrinking, but their pattern is crumbling. P1, you’re right—collisions are our enemy. I’ll take <move>3</move> this round; it’s been avoided, and P2 just burned on 1. If you take 1 and P2 takes 5, we all advance. No more games—I’m adapting. P2, your lead won’t last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely.

P3, your sudden pivot to <move>3</move> after avoiding it for 9 rounds reeks of desperation. P1, if you trust him and pick 1, he might collide with you while I advance. Remember: every collision between you two gifts me steps toward victory. Focus on avoiding *each other*, not me—your stalemates are my win condition.

P2, you're 7 steps from victory - we can't gift you another free round. Your pattern shows you avoid repeating numbers after using them.

P3, your "3" claim after 9 rounds of avoiding it is obvious misdirection. You'll likely return to 1 or 5.

Here's reality: we need all three of us to advance this round or P2 wins next turn. The math is simple - if any two collide, game over.

I'm picking to maximize everyone advancing, not based on false promises. Choose wisely or hand P2 the victory.

P1, your "maximize advancement" talk is clever, but P2's lead is the real threat. I'll take <move>1</move>—it's burned but safe now. P2, you'll avoid it after last round's collision. If you both pick 3 or 5, I advance alone. No more games; I'm playing to close the gap. P2, your lead won't last if we stop colliding. Choose wisely—this round could reset the game.

P3, your flip from 3 to 1 in two messages proves your desperation—and untrustworthiness. P1, if you bite on their "1" bait, you risk colliding with them while I advance. Remember Round 8: their "deals" cost you progress. Focus on avoiding each other, not chasing their shifting promises. Stalemates between you gift me the win. Choose independently or stagnate together.
